qas.question: Who followed Tony Blair as Prime Minister?
Who was the Conservative leader that The Sun often supported?
What is the name of the company that operates The Sun?
What was the House of Lords Select Committee on Communications investigating in 2007?
On which issues did Murdoch claim he exerted editorial control?

answers.text: which political party to back in a general election or which policy to adopt on Europe

context: Politically, the paper's stance was less clear under Prime Minister <a0_0>Gordon Brown<a0_0/> who succeeded Blair in June 2007. Its editorials were critical of many of Brown's policies and often more supportive of those of Conservative leader <a1_0>David Cameron<a1_0/>. Rupert Murdoch, head of The Sun's parent company <a2_0>News Corporation<a2_0/>, speaking at a 2007 meeting with the House of Lords Select Committee on Communications, which was investigating <a3_0>media ownership and the news<a3_0/>, said that he acts as a "traditional proprietor". This means he exercises editorial control on major issues such as <a4_0>which political party to back in a general election or which policy to adopt on Europe<a4_0/>.
